title.narrative: CAPACITY OF CAREGIVERS

description.narrative: Output 1.1: Parents and caregivers, especially adolescent mothers, have improved uptake of positive Early Child Development (ECD), health, HIV and nutrition practices., which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Cross Sectoral - Gender Discriminatory Roles And Practices, Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence (Covid), Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition In Early Childhood (Covid), Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Girls and boys, aged 0-5, in targeted districts, with a focus on the first 1,000 days, benefit from early learning, caring, nurturing, a clean and protective environment and quality, integrated, high-impact interventions.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 1.1: Parents and caregivers, especially adolescent mothers, have improved uptake of positive ECD, health, HIV andnutrition practices.

description.narrative: A total of 4,905,609 parents and caregiver’s increased their knowledge and skills on Early Childhood Development (ECD), health, Human Immuno Virus (HIV) and nutrition leading to improved early stimulation, nutrition and positive parenting practices and responsive caregiving and quality of diets for 347,725 children between 0-23 months. At least 864,654 parents and caregivers were reached through parenting programmes using different platforms, including home visiting services and parenting education messages through community radios, resulted in improved care practices including health, nutrition, prevention of violent parenting discipline, play and stimulation, early learning and safety and security. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:16/12/2021
